# AI 2026: How Tech Hubs Are Reshaping the Newsroom

*Silicon Valley is racing into 2026 with new AI models, and newsrooms are still playing catch-up.*

I spent the week buried in press releases from Apple and OpenAI, and it feels like d√©j√† vu. Every year it‚Äôs a fresh round of promises, but this year the stakes are different. If you‚Äôre running a newsroom in 2026, you‚Äôre not just chasing shiny tools. You‚Äôre trying to survive their impact.

**üìã This Week in AI: Tech Hubs and Tidal Waves**

Apple‚Äôs new AI integration for news apps is everywhere right now. On paper, it‚Äôs called Apple News Intelligence. It scrapes, summarizes, and ‚Äúpersonalizes‚Äù the news feed on every iPhone and iPad. The big feature? Contextual recommendations based on your reading history and location. But when I tried it, it felt like an old trick in a new interface. Apple is still pulling from the same pool of wire stories and publisher feeds‚Äîjust now with a layer of AI-filtered headlines. 

Behind the curtain, it‚Äôs more about keeping users inside the Apple ecosystem than real innovation. The talk is about ‚Äúserving the right story at the right time.‚Äù The reality: more algorithmic curation, less editorial control for actual journalists. [PLACEHOLDER: need source on newsroom feedback to Apple News Intelligence.]

OpenAI‚Äôs partnership with Reuters is the other headline. Reuters will license its archive and live news wire to OpenAI, feeding ChatGPT and other models with real-time updates and (presumably) better training data. Who wins? OpenAI, obviously. They get a global news pipeline for their bots. Reuters gets a big cheque and maybe a foot in the door for new distribution. But smaller publishers lose out. If you‚Äôre not Reuters, you‚Äôre now even less visible on the platforms that matter.

I spoke to a tech editor at a mid-sized European publisher this week. She‚Äôs worried her newsroom will slide further down the food chain‚Äîmore invisible, less essential. OpenAI isn‚Äôt partnering with her, and there‚Äôs no seat at the table for independent voices. It‚Äôs the same story: the big get bigger, the rest scramble for scraps.

Google quietly rolled out a major update to Gemini. Western newsrooms barely blinked. The new feature? Automated ‚Äúnews briefs‚Äù that pull from local outlets and generate summaries for Google Discover and Assistant. I tested it with a few UK and US local news stories. The AI versions are bland, accurate, but soulless. They strip out any hint of personality. That‚Äôs the point: scale up news, strip out friction, and keep users on Google‚Äôs pages. There‚Äôs almost no credit given to the original outlets. I haven‚Äôt seen a single publisher outside the big US brands happy about this.

**üè† What‚Äôs Happening at Develop AI**

I‚Äôm launching a new series: AI Toolkits for Small Newsrooms. The first batch is aimed at Western partners‚Äîthink local publishers in the UK, small dailies in France, and indie newsrooms in Canada. The goal is simple: show what you can actually use, not what Silicon Valley is hyping this week. There‚Äôs a gap opening up between what‚Äôs being sold and what‚Äôs genuinely useful for real newsrooms. I want to close that gap.

Over the past month, I‚Äôve been consulting with a UK-based publisher testing automated local news feeds. They‚Äôre using a mix of ChatGPT, NewsWhip, and their own CMS triggers. The results: traffic is up, but engagement is flat. Automated weather and traffic updates are easy wins. But when they tried more complex local council coverage, the AI missed context and nuance every time. Their editors are now treating AI as a drafting tool‚Äînever the final word. It‚Äôs saving time, but not replacing anyone yet.

Next week, I‚Äôll be on a panel at MIT Media Lab: ‚ÄúAI and the Newsroom: Lessons from Silicon Valley.‚Äù The other speakers are all from US startups or big tech. I‚Äôll be the only one with hands-on experience in smaller, less-resourced newsrooms. My take? We need to stop treating every tool as if it works out of the box. Context, workflow, and actual newsroom needs matter more than whatever Google demoed last week.

**üëã See you next week.**

The pace of Western AI releases is relentless. Every week it‚Äôs another ‚Äúbreakthrough‚Äù from Apple, OpenAI, or Google. Most of it is incremental. Some of it‚Äôs useful. None of it is slowing down.

If you want more real-world breakdowns (and fewer buzzwords), subscribe for the next issue. I‚Äôll keep tracking Silicon Valley‚Äôs latest move, so you don‚Äôt have to.

All the best,

Paul

Stay alert: the Western tech giants are moving fast, and if you‚Äôre working in media, you need to keep up‚Äîor risk being left behind.

# Why AI in 2026 is Less Impressive Than You Think

*Everyone says AI in 2026 is unstoppable. My experience this week says otherwise.*

I spent most of last week toggling between Google‚Äôs latest Gemini for Workspace and OpenAI‚Äôs new ‚ÄúOmni-Assist‚Äù layer in ChatGPT Pro. The marketing is everywhere‚ÄîYouTube pre-rolls, LinkedIn posts, those endless Substack threads telling you to ‚Äúembrace the future.‚Äù But after a week of actual use, I‚Äôm left thinking: This is it?

I‚Äôm not saying nothing has changed. But for journalists and media people, the 2026 upgrade cycle feels like a familiar sales pitch in a different wrapper. Let me break down what‚Äôs real, what‚Äôs recycled, and what actually helps.

---

**üõ†Ô∏è Tools & Tips: What Actually Works in 2026**

1. **Google Gemini for Workspace**

Here‚Äôs what they promise: fully integrated research, summarisation, and auto-drafting in Docs, Sheets, and even Gmail. Supposedly, you feed Gemini your notes, interview transcripts, and it spits out ‚Äúpolished, accurate, bias-free articles.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what actually happens: I threw a week‚Äôs worth of interview notes (real, messy, a mix of WhatsApp voice notes and Google Meet transcriptions) into Gemini inside Docs. The first summary missed the main quote from an editor at *Mail & Guardian* entirely. The draft it generated for a story on load-shedding relied on two-year-old stats from a World Bank PDF I‚Äôd uploaded as ‚Äúbackground.‚Äù It hallucinated an interview with Eskom that I never did.

I tried the same workflow with OpenAI‚Äôs new ‚ÄúOmni-Assist‚Äù plugin in ChatGPT Pro. It‚Äôs meant to ‚Äúcontextualise‚Äù your news gathering by tying together web data, old PDFs, and live chats. But the first result was a Frankenstein of phrases from my own reporting, mixed with whole sentences lifted from *Reuters* coverage. I ran the output through Copyleaks and got 48% flagged as duplicate content.

> **AI lesson:** The only real productivity gain is in grunt work. Gemini is decent at cleaning up your calendar, finding double-booked interviews, and sorting sources by date. But for reporting, context, and quotes‚Äîstill manual. If you‚Äôre looking for a workflow hack, use Gemini to sift through your messy calendar invites and emails, but do not trust it with the actual story.

2. **The Workflow That‚Äôs Actually Useful**

I‚Äôm still using *Otter.ai* (yes, still around) for transcribing WhatsApp voice notes, especially for interviews in noisy environments. Then I drop the transcripts into [NEED: new, reliable summarisation tool]‚Äînot Gemini, not OpenAI‚Äîand do a side-by-side check with my own notes. It‚Äôs slower, but at least I‚Äôm not publishing AI-invented sources.

> **If you‚Äôre a journalist:** Use the AI to clean and sort your data. Don‚Äôt let it near your final copy. Never trust an ‚Äúauto-summary‚Äù to catch nuance or intent.

---

**üîÆ Future / Predictions: Same Old Biases, Same Old Problems**

I‚Äôve read half a dozen ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Next For AI in Media?‚Äù think pieces this month. They all say the same thing: ‚ÄúThis time it‚Äôs different.‚Äù It isn‚Äôt.

- **Quality is still unreliable.** I spoke to [NEED: editor at Daily Maverick] who said their experiment with Gemini-generated newsletters lasted two weeks. Too many hallucinations, not enough unique voice. Their audience noticed the change and engagement dropped.

- **Language and local context? Still bad.** Google and OpenAI both claim ‚Äúmajor improvements‚Äù in African language support, but when I tested Gemini with Setswana and Yoruba, the results were embarrassing. Names misspelled, context lost, and quotes mangled. [NEED: link to failed Setswana summary]

- **Western focus dominates.** The big feature drops‚Äîthe ‚ÄúAI Newsroom Dashboard‚Äù from Microsoft, the new ‚ÄúFact-Check‚Äù plugin for ChatGPT, even Google‚Äôs local news recommendations‚Äîare all piloted in the US, UK, or Germany. I have yet to see a single African newsroom get early access without a partner grant from DW Akademie or IMS footing the bill.

- **2027 prediction:** Unless one of these giants radically opens up their models or actually builds with journalists outside New York and London, we‚Äôre in for another year of incremental upgrades. Slightly better summaries. Maybe a new ‚Äúdiversity‚Äù sticker. But nothing that changes the day-to-day grind for real reporters.

---

**2026‚Äôs AI: The Same Faces in Different Hoodies**

The parade hasn‚Äôt changed‚ÄîOpenAI, Google, Microsoft, Meta. Every ‚Äúnew‚Äù feature is mostly a remix: Gemini‚Äôs ‚ÄúLive Research‚Äù is just a rebranded Google Alerts with chat. ChatGPT‚Äôs ‚ÄúOmni-Assist‚Äù feels like a souped-up Chrome extension from 2022. And every major AI launch still features the same row of white men in hoodies talking about ‚Äúdemocratising information.‚Äù

The diversity push? I see more slides about ‚Äúinclusion‚Äù at conferences, but I don‚Äôt see more African or Latin American newsrooms in the pilots. Most teams I talk to in Johannesburg or Nairobi are still running open-source models on borrowed GPUs or using Hugging Face endpoints because the big boys won‚Äôt unlock their APIs without a credit card and a Delaware registration.

> **If you want to dodge the hype:** Ignore the ‚Äúbreakthrough‚Äù launches. Look for open-source stuff on Hugging Face, or try [NEED: specific African LLM] if you want local context. The best work I‚Äôve seen in the past two months is a WhatsApp-based news bot for community radio in Uganda, built with open tools and no VC money.

---

**What‚Äôs Happening at Develop AI**

I‚Äôve just wrapped a training cycle with DW Akademie on AI for audio newsrooms‚Äîlots of focus on podcast workflows, WhatsApp distribution, and why you shouldn‚Äôt trust AI to write your show notes. Next up: co-hosting an AI in journalism panel at the Global Media Forum in Bonn. If you‚Äôre there, come say hi.

I‚Äôm also piloting a project with [NEED: South African newsroom] to build a true local language news assistant. If you‚Äôre working on something similar, or want to test your workflow against Gemini, drop me a line.

All the best,

Paul

# AI 2026: How Silicon Valley's New Bets Will Shape Your Newsroom

*Silicon Valley is moving fast on AI in 2026, but newsrooms are already playing catch up.*

This week has been a blur of launches and announcements, most of them coming from the big end of the tech pool. I‚Äôve spent the last few days trawling through Apple keynotes, OpenAI press releases, and the usual flood of Google blog posts. The story, as always, isn‚Äôt just about the shiny new tools. It‚Äôs about what gets left behind, and who‚Äôs actually going to use any of this.

---

## üìã This Week‚Äôs AI News Roundup

### 1. Apple‚Äôs M4 Chip and On-Device AI

Apple finally rolled out the M4 chip, and the press is calling it the ‚ÄúAI MacBook.‚Äù The real story is that Apple‚Äôs moving away from cloud-heavy LLMs and pushing everything onto the device itself. That means your news app (or your CMS, if you‚Äôre fancy) could soon be running its own mini AI model, without sending data anywhere.

The pitch: privacy, speed, and ‚Äúpersonalised content.‚Äù The reality: most publishers are nowhere near ready for this. I spoke to a tech lead at [NEED: name of UK regional publisher] who said they‚Äôre still using a WordPress plugin from 2017 to manage their newsletters. But Apple‚Äôs demo of on-device summarisation and speech-to-text is impressive. If you‚Äôre running editorial workflows on a MacBook, you‚Äôll see these features creep in by default.

> **AI lesson:**  
> If you‚Äôre producing sensitive content, on-device AI could help you keep your user data away from OpenAI or Google. But you‚Äôll also need to rethink how you train and update your models‚Äîbecause you can‚Äôt just ship everything to the cloud and hope for the best.

### 2. OpenAI + Reuters: News Summaries, Again

OpenAI announced a partnership with Reuters to deliver ‚ÄúAI-powered news summaries.‚Äù If this sounds familiar, it‚Äôs because it is. We‚Äôve seen similar deals with Associated Press, Axel Springer, and a few others. What‚Äôs actually new is the integration: Reuters is giving OpenAI a direct newsfeed to train and update their models, not just a one-off archive dump.

I got a look at the beta via a friend at Reuters. The summaries are fast, but they‚Äôre bland. No context, no local flavour, just the facts. That‚Äôs fine for a newswire, but not if you want your reporting to stand out. The interesting bit? Reuters gets a window into how OpenAI is using their content, at least in theory. Most African publishers are still locked out of these deals, and there are zero transparency guarantees on how this data will be used downstream.

> **AI lesson:**  
> If you‚Äôre a newsroom thinking about licensing deals or model training, ask for audit rights. See how your content is being used‚Äîdon‚Äôt just take the money and walk away.

### 3. Google Gemini 2.0: Search and Workspace Get Smarter, Publishers Get Sidelined

Google‚Äôs new Gemini 2.0 is now baked into Search and Workspace. If you‚Äôre using Docs, Gmail, or even Sheets, you‚Äôve probably seen the ‚ÄúHelp me write‚Äù button get a lot more persistent. The bigger impact is in Search‚ÄîAI overviews are now the first thing users see, pushing publisher links even further down the page.

I ran a test this week with a group of journalism students at Wits University. We searched for basic news topics‚Äîload shedding updates, local council elections, the usual. The Gemini-powered answers were fast and accurate, but the source links were hidden behind a ‚ÄúShow more‚Äù button. Most students never clicked through. If you‚Äôre a publisher, expect your traffic to drop even further.

> **AI lesson:**  
> Don‚Äôt build your business on Google referrals. Start moving your content onto channels you control‚Äînewsletters, WhatsApp, SMS, anything that isn‚Äôt filtered by an algorithm in Mountain View.

### 4. The Deeper Issue: Who Gets Left Out?

All these announcements have a common thread: big tech companies are consolidating power, but the tools are getting more closed off. Apple‚Äôs on-device AI is only for people who can afford the latest hardware. OpenAI‚Äôs partnerships are with the biggest wire services. Google‚Äôs Gemini is tuned for the US and Europe first, with African and Asian languages still a distant afterthought.

I spoke to [NEED: name of Tanzanian editor] about how their newsroom is using AI. They‚Äôre still relying on WhatsApp groups and manual fact-checking, because none of these new tools support Swahili properly. Even the best text-to-speech models butcher local names and phrases. The risk is that the next wave of AI will be even more exclusionary than the last.

> **AI lesson:**  
> If you‚Äôre in Africa or the Global South, don‚Äôt wait for Silicon Valley to build the tools you need. Start experimenting with open-source models, or partner with local developers. The gap is only going to widen if you don‚Äôt build your own solutions.

### 5. Practical Takeaways for Newsrooms

1. **Audit your tech stack.** If you‚Äôre still relying on Google or Facebook for traffic, start diversifying now.
2. **Test on-device AI.** Try the new M4 MacBooks or iPads‚Äîsee what you can actually do with local models.
3. **Push for transparency.** If you‚Äôre licensing content, demand insight into how your work is being used.
4. **Experiment with open models.** Don‚Äôt wait for the big players to localise‚Äîtry tools like Hugging Face, Cohere, or open-source LLMs.
5. **Keep your audience close.** Newsletters, WhatsApp, SMS‚Äîall still work, and you own the relationship.

> **Key takeaway:**  
> The future of AI in newsrooms won‚Äôt be decided in Cupertino or San Francisco. It‚Äôll be shaped by whoever actually builds and adapts these tools to fit real workflows‚Äîand that can (and should) be you.

# AI 2026: How to Actually Use What Silicon Valley Is Building

*The West is already moving on to the next AI obsession. Everyone else is still cleaning up the mess.*

I spent two days last month in a Johannesburg newsroom staring at the same ‚ÄúAI-powered news dashboard‚Äù demo that the New York Times used in 2024. Two years later, the US has moved on to AGI panic and ‚Äúsentient editorial assistants.‚Äù Meanwhile, we‚Äôre still trying to get the bylines right on AI rewrites of council minutes. This is what Silicon Valley does: launch, abandon, repeat.

But plenty of people aren‚Äôt waiting for the next miracle. They‚Äôre making these half-finished tools work‚Äîsometimes in ways OpenAI never imagined. That‚Äôs what actually matters in 2026.

---

**1. The Core Issue: Silicon Valley Moves On, The Rest of Us Patch the Holes**

Silicon Valley cycles through AI trends like TikTok dances. Last year it was AI video tools. Now it‚Äôs ‚Äúautonomous agents‚Äù and whatever OpenAI is teasing next. But every time a new model drops, the hype cycle restarts and the old problems get swept under the rug.

Newsrooms outside the US, especially those in Africa and Southeast Asia, are often left with the ‚Äúlegacy‚Äù versions and little technical support. The result? You get a Frankenstein‚Äôs monster of tools, plugins, and Google Sheets, all duct-taped together to meet deadlines.

When I was in Accra, the Daily Graphic‚Äôs digital team showed me their Gemini-powered news aggregator. It scrapes local WhatsApp groups and pushes summaries to their Telegram channel. Is it pretty? No. Is it effective? Yes. They‚Äôre not waiting for Google to localize Project Mercury‚Äîthey‚Äôre hacking it together themselves.

---

**2. Deep Analysis: The Real Work is Unsexy**

The big AI headlines are always about ‚Äúdisruption.‚Äù But the real work is a lot less glamorous. It‚Äôs about using OpenAI‚Äôs models to automate the boring stuff‚Äîrewriting press releases, translating into local languages, prepping data for the 6am newsletter.

Nobody at the Guardian is sending prompts to ChatGPT for the front page. But they are using AI to check facts, flag potential legal issues, and speed up subbing. I‚Äôve seen the same at The Namibian and at El Tiempo in Colombia. These aren‚Äôt shiny ‚Äúgenerative‚Äù projects; they‚Äôre workflow hacks.

The problem is, most of these tools are built for English, and they‚Äôre trained on US data. So you end up spending half your time fixing translation errors or tweaking summary prompts so they don‚Äôt hallucinate Zimbabwean ministers. The gap between what‚Äôs promised and what actually gets used is massive.

---

**3. Real Examples: Newsrooms Making It Work**

- **NYT**: Still using a custom version of ChatGPT for first drafts, but with a human editor rewriting everything for voice and accuracy. The AI is good at bullet points, bad at context. [NEED: name of NYT digital editor]
- **Der Spiegel**: Created an in-house ‚Äúmini-LLM‚Äù trained on Spiegel archives. Used mainly for background research and to surface old reporting. It‚Äôs slow, but the journalists trust it more than GPT-4.
- **The Continent (South Africa)**: Uses WhatsApp bots built on open-source LLMs to gather reader tips and auto-tag stories for follow-up. I helped them build the first version in Python, but they‚Äôve since migrated to a no-code platform.
- **Daily Graphic (Ghana)**: Their Gemini hack mentioned above‚Äîno support from Google, but it works for getting rural stories surfaced in Accra.

> **AI lesson:** Stop waiting for the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù tool. Use what‚Äôs available, patch the gaps, and build your own glue. The best AI projects in news are never off-the-shelf.

---

**4. The Africa/Global South Angle: More Risk, More Ingenuity**

The gap between flashy demos and working software is wider in the Global South. Here, ‚ÄúAI integration‚Äù usually means a WhatsApp bot and three Google Forms. But that means more room for improvisation.

I‚Äôve seen newsrooms in Lagos using open weights from Meta‚Äôs Llama 3, fine-tuned on Nigerian English. In Nairobi, journalists are stringing together free APIs to build their own headline generators because the mainstream ones can‚Äôt handle local names.

The dark side is dependency. When Google or Meta quietly kill a product, there‚Äôs no backup. I‚Äôve watched whole news projects collapse because an ‚ÄúAI-powered‚Äù WhatsApp number went offline after a Meta update.

---

**5. Practical Takeaway: Make AI Your Servant, Not Your Master**

AI is the new CMS: messy, undercooked, but you‚Äôre stuck with it. Stop waiting for the next release from San Francisco. Build on what‚Äôs here. Document your hacks. Share with other newsrooms.

> **What you can do:**
> 1. Pick one AI tool‚ÄîGemini, ChatGPT, Llama, whatever‚Äîand use it for a single workflow.
> 2. Keep a log of what breaks and how you fix it.
> 3. Share your fixes. I‚Äôll publish the best ones in this newsletter.

The future isn‚Äôt going to be delivered from the cloud. You‚Äôre building it every day.

---

Automation helps with summaries, but editorial judgment still needs a human. Layoffs are up, AI-powered content is everywhere, and nobody agrees on what counts as ‚Äúoriginal reporting‚Äù anymore.

# Here is how to use AI on your past newsletter stats and create a fresh one that hits every day

*I rebuilt my own newsletter archive using AI tools‚Äîand you can too. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide.*

I spent last week rebuilding the entire Develop AI newsletter archive. Not by hand. Not with another endless spreadsheet. I did it with a couple of AI prompts, a few copy-pastes, and a bit of time staring at Google Colab. The result? I can now remix old issues, find which topics hit hardest, and generate fresh editions that actually land every single day.

This is a huge step up from the usual ‚Äúpublish and forget‚Äù cycle. Most newsletters, especially here in Africa, get sent out, maybe shared once, then vanish into the void. I wanted to see if AI could change that. Not just for me, but for any journalist, editor, or small newsroom that wants to squeeze more value out of what they‚Äôve already made.

**Why this matters now**

The myth: you need to be a coder, have a data team, or subscribe to some Silicon Valley platform to do any of this. Not true. You need ChatGPT, Claude, or Google Colab (all tools I‚Äôve written about and used in the last few months). That‚Äôs it.

The smarter newsrooms in the US and Europe have been running these kinds of ‚Äúcontent surfacing‚Äù workflows for years. But they‚Äôre usually built on expensive systems, or hidden behind the paywall of whatever Substack is rolling out next. Meanwhile, small teams in Lagos or Nairobi are sitting on years of untapped stories, newsletters, and podcasts that could be repackaged, translated, or just made visible again. It‚Äôs not about automation for its own sake. It‚Äôs about reach.

**How I did it (and how you can too)**

Here‚Äôs the workflow I landed on:

1. **Export your newsletter archive.**  
   For Substack, just go to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and hit ‚ÄúExport.‚Äù For Mailchimp, same story. You want a CSV or spreadsheet with all your past issues, dates, and subject lines.

2. **Paste into ChatGPT or Claude.**  
   I used ChatGPT-4o for this. Prompt: ‚ÄúSummarise the top themes, most opened issues, and which topics had the highest click rates.‚Äù It spat out a rough ranking and a list of ‚Äúmost engaging‚Äù stories. It even grouped similar topics (AI video, podcasting, coding tips).

3. **Feed it into Google Colab.**  
   This is where it gets more interesting. I asked ChatGPT to generate Python code that would pull in my spreadsheet, analyse open rates, and cluster topics by popularity. I‚Äôm not a developer, but this step took less than 30 minutes. You copy, paste, run.  
   _(If you get stuck, message me. I‚Äôll share the exact code I used.)_

4. **Generate new newsletter drafts.**

20260101_124207.content:
The AI revolution is poised to reshape the workforce, and investors are buzzing. According to a report from PwC, nearly 60% of jobs will see substantial changes, with AI taking over a whopping 30% of tasks.

The excitement is palpable, especially in Silicon Valley. A study from Stanford shows that 40% of California's workforce is at risk of displacement due to AI. However, the message is clear: this is not just about losing jobs; it's about transforming them.

The AI market is projected to skyrocket. In 2023, it was valued at $86 billion; by 2030, that figure is expected to soar to $1.5 trillion. This growth is attracting a flood of capital. In Q1 2024 alone, AI startups raised $4.25 billion globally, with an impressive 83% of that coming from the US. This influx is not just about numbers; it's about innovation and potential.

But what does this mean for industries? The impact will vary. In the manufacturing sector, AI is set to enhance efficiency and precision. For healthcare, it promises better diagnostics and patient care. However, sectors like transportation and retail are bracing for more upheaval.

This shift isn't just about technology; it's about reskilling. A report from McKinsey emphasizes the need for a rapid upskilling of the workforce. Employees will need to adapt to new tools and processes to stay relevant.

In Africa, the potential for AI to drive economic growth is immense. A report from the Brookings Institution highlights that AI could add $1.5 trillion to Africa's economy by 2030. However, there's a caveat: for this to happen, investments in education and infrastructure are crucial.

As we look to 2026 and beyond, the message is clear: embrace the change. AI will transform our work lives, and those who adapt will thrive.

20260101_130221.content:
# 2026 is coming for your job: The rise of AI in the workplace

2026 is the year AI stops being an abstract threat and starts knocking on your office door. I can feel it. I was in Johannesburg last month, talking with editors at the Daily Maverick about their plans for next year. The anxiety was real. Everyone wanted to know: ‚ÄúWill my job make it through the next cycle of AI upgrades?‚Äù

It‚Äôs not just media. Every industry is getting the same existential memo. And it‚Äôs not hype‚Äîinvestors are openly predicting that 2026 will be the year AI comes for labour, not just in Silicon Valley but everywhere. (Here‚Äôs the piece from TechCrunch if you want to see what the money people are betting on: [Investors predict AI is coming for labor in 2026](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/).)

---

## The real story: AI isn‚Äôt just about job loss

I‚Äôve seen a lot of hand-wringing about AI ‚Äúreplacing‚Äù jobs. The truth is a little more complicated. Yes, repetitive, rules-based jobs are getting automated. If your job is to process data, fill in forms, or do basic analysis, the writing is on the wall. The bots are coming.

But here‚Äôs what almost nobody says out loud: AI creates new jobs, too. They just don‚Äôt look like the old ones. In media, I‚Äôve watched newsrooms in Lagos and Nairobi pivot to hiring people who can manage AI workflows, build prompts, and evaluate machine output for bias or error. These jobs didn‚Äôt exist two years ago.

> **AI lesson:** If you want to survive, you need to be learning how to work *with* AI, not just avoiding it.

The jobs that stick around? The ones involving complex problem-solving, creativity, or emotional intelligence. Editors who can spot a story AI misses. Journalists who can build trust in communities and verify information the bots scrape from the web. It‚Äôs the same in health, law, and education.

---

## The deeper issue: Transformation, not just attrition

A lot of the conversation is still stuck on the idea that AI will ‚Äúreplace‚Äù humans. Wrong frame. AI is transforming the *nature* of work. Take podcasting. In Moldova, I saw newsrooms using ElevenLabs to generate synthetic voices for daily news briefings. But the audience noticed when the stories sounded robotic or tone-deaf to real events. The lesson: AI can draft, but humans still have to sense-check and add context.

In South Africa, I‚Äôve helped a couple of outlets set up semi-automated newsletter workflows. The time saved is real. But it‚Äôs not about cutting staff. The goal is to free up journalists to do deeper reporting‚Äîinvestigations, podcasts, WhatsApp tip lines‚Äîwhile the AI handles the daily churn.

The best newsrooms aren‚Äôt firing people. They‚Äôre upskilling them. They‚Äôre teaching staff to use ChatGPT for research, but also running workshops on media ethics, context, and how to spot an AI hallucination from a mile away.

---

## Real examples: What‚Äôs actually happening now

1. **In Nairobi**, The Elephant has started using AI to translate stories into Swahili and French. Human editors still do the final pass, but the AI gets them 80% of the way.
2. **In Cape Town**, a small investigative team I worked with is building an archive search tool using open-source LLMs from Ollama. The journalists can now search decades of court filings in seconds‚Äîbut they still have to call sources to check what‚Äôs real.
3. **At DW Akademie‚Äôs recent workshop in Uganda**, the focus was on teaching community journalists how to use AI to summarise WhatsApp group chats, so they can spot trends without reading thousands of messages. Automation, but with a human in the loop.

---

## The Global South: Different risks, different opportunities

Here‚Äôs what keeps me up at night. Most of the conversation about AI and jobs is still dominated by American and European voices. But the risks‚Äîand the opportunities‚Äîare different in Africa and the Global South.

If you‚Äôre in Lagos or Nairobi, you probably don‚Äôt have a giant HR department to retrain everyone. The threat isn‚Äôt just job loss, but being locked out of the new jobs entirely. The skills gap is real‚Äîand so is the infrastructure gap.

But there‚Äôs also a window for leapfrogging. African newsrooms are some of the fastest to adopt WhatsApp bots, automated translation, and local-language podcasting. I‚Äôve seen more innovation in small, underfunded teams in Accra than in entire European newsrooms with ten times the budget.

If governments and funders step up‚Äîby investing in digital skills training, open-source tools, and decent internet‚Äîthere‚Äôs a chance to build a new kind of workforce. But we need to move fast.

---

## What you should actually do

- Audit your job. What do you do that AI could already do? What‚Äôs left that only you can do?
- Start learning new tools‚ÄîCursor, ChatGPT, ElevenLabs‚Äîbefore your boss tells you to.
- If you‚Äôre a decision-maker, invest in upskilling, not just cutting costs.
- Push for a real social safety net. Universal basic income isn‚Äôt a Silicon Valley daydream; it might be the only way some people get through this.

> **Takeaway:** AI isn‚Äôt coming for *all* jobs. It‚Äôs coming for the parts of your job that can be automated. Make sure what‚Äôs left is worth keeping.

---

## üìã This Week in AI News

- **AI Regulation:** Big tech is lobbying hard to water down new AI regulations in Europe and Asia. The fight is over who gets to decide what counts as ‚Äúhigh-risk.‚Äù (Search: 'AI regulation news 2026')
- **AI in Education:** Schools in Kenya and South Africa are starting to flag declining learning outcomes where AI ‚Äútutors‚Äù have replaced real teachers. The debate is heating up over how much automation is too much for the classroom. (Search: 'AI education impact 2026')

---

## üè† What‚Äôs Happening at Develop AI

We‚Äôve been shortlisted for Best Podcasting Innovation at this year‚Äôs South African Podcast Awards. It‚Äôs a big deal for us, considering we started as a newsletter and now we‚Äôre competing with national broadcasters.

I‚Äôll also be speaking at the European University Institute in Florence on 30 November 2026. My panel is all about AI, podcasting, and what ‚ÄúEuropean values‚Äù even mean when half the content you consume is generated by a bot. If you‚Äôre in Italy, come say hi.

We‚Äôre always building, always testing. If you want to see how AI can actually help your newsroom‚Äînot just replace people but build something new‚Äîreply to this email or join our WhatsApp Community.

All the best,

Paul

# 2026 is coming for your job: The rise of AI in the workplace

2026 is the year AI stops being an abstract threat and starts knocking on your office door. I can feel it. I was in Johannesburg last month, talking with editors at the Daily Maverick about their plans for next year. The anxiety was real. Everyone wanted to know: ‚ÄúWill my job make it through the next cycle of AI upgrades?‚Äù

It‚Äôs not just media. Every industry is getting the same existential memo. And it‚Äôs not hype‚Äîinvestors are openly predicting that 2026 will be the year AI comes for labour, not just in Silicon Valley but everywhere. (Here‚Äôs the piece from TechCrunch if you want to see what the money people are betting on: [Investors predict AI is coming for labor in 2026](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/).)

---

## The real story: AI isn‚Äôt just about job loss

I‚Äôve seen a lot of hand-wringing about AI ‚Äúreplacing‚Äù jobs. The truth is a little more complicated. Yes, repetitive, rules-based jobs are getting automated. If your job is to process data, fill in forms, or do basic analysis, the writing is on the wall. The bots are coming.

But here‚Äôs what almost nobody says out loud: AI creates new jobs, too. They just don‚Äôt look like the old ones. In media, I‚Äôve watched newsrooms in Lagos and Nairobi pivot to hiring people who can manage AI workflows, build prompts, and evaluate machine output for bias or error. These jobs didn‚Äôt exist two years ago.

> **AI lesson:** If you want to survive, you need to be learning how to work *with* AI, not just avoiding it.

The jobs that stick around? The ones involving complex problem-solving, creativity, or emotional intelligence. Editors who can spot a story AI misses. Journalists who can build trust in communities and verify information the bots scrape from the web. It‚Äôs the same in health, law, and education.

---

## The deeper issue: Transformation, not just attrition

A lot of the conversation is still stuck on the idea that AI will ‚Äúreplace‚Äù humans. Wrong frame. AI is transforming the *nature* of work. Take podcasting. In Moldova, I saw newsrooms using ElevenLabs to generate synthetic voices for daily news briefings. But the audience noticed when the stories sounded robotic or tone-deaf to real events. The lesson: AI can draft, but humans still have to sense-check and add context.

In South Africa, I‚Äôve helped a couple of outlets set up semi-automated newsletter workflows. The time saved is real. But it‚Äôs not about cutting staff. The goal is to free up journalists to do deeper reporting‚Äîinvestigations, podcasts, WhatsApp tip lines‚Äîwhile the AI handles the daily churn.

The best newsrooms aren‚Äôt firing people. They‚Äôre upskilling them. They‚Äôre teaching staff to use ChatGPT for research, but also running workshops on media ethics, context, and how to spot an AI hallucination from a mile away.

---

## Real examples: What‚Äôs actually happening now

1. **In Nairobi**, The Elephant has started using AI to translate stories into Swahili and French. Human editors still do the final pass, but the AI gets them 80% of the way.
2. **In Cape Town**, a small investigative team I worked with is building an archive search tool using open-source LLMs from Ollama. The journalists can now search decades of court filings in seconds‚Äîbut they still have to call sources to check what‚Äôs real.
3. **At DW Akademie‚Äôs recent workshop in Uganda**, the focus was on teaching community journalists how to use AI to summarise WhatsApp group chats, so they can spot trends without reading thousands of messages. Automation, but with a human in the loop.

---

## The Global South: Different risks, different opportunities

Here‚Äôs what keeps me up at night. Most of the conversation about AI and jobs is still dominated by American and European voices. But the risks‚Äîand the opportunities‚Äîare different in Africa and the Global South.

If you‚Äôre in Lagos or Nairobi, you probably don‚Äôt have a giant HR department to retrain everyone. The threat isn‚Äôt just job loss, but being locked out of the new jobs entirely. The skills gap is real‚Äîand so is the infrastructure gap.

But there‚Äôs also a window for leapfrogging. African newsrooms are some of the fastest to adopt WhatsApp bots, automated translation, and local-language podcasting. I‚Äôve seen more innovation in small, underfunded teams in Accra than in entire European newsrooms with ten times the budget.

If governments and funders step up‚Äîby investing in digital skills training, open-source tools, and decent internet‚Äîthere‚Äôs a chance to build a new kind of workforce. But we need to move fast.

---

## What you should actually do

- Audit your job. What do you do that AI could already do? What‚Äôs left that only you can do?
- Start learning new tools‚ÄîCursor, ChatGPT, ElevenLabs‚Äîbefore your boss tells you to.
- If you‚Äôre a decision-maker, invest in upskilling, not just cutting costs.
- Push for a real social safety net. Universal basic income isn‚Äôt a Silicon Valley daydream; it might be the only way some people get through this.

> **Takeaway:** AI isn‚Äôt coming for *all* jobs. It‚Äôs coming for the parts of your job that can be automated. Make sure what‚Äôs left is worth keeping.

---

## üìã This Week in AI News

- **AI Regulation:** Big tech is lobbying hard to water down new AI regulations in Europe and Asia. The fight is over who gets to decide what counts as ‚Äúhigh-risk.‚Äù (Search: 'AI regulation news 2026')
- **AI in Education:** Schools in Kenya and South Africa are starting to flag declining learning outcomes where AI ‚Äútutors‚Äù have replaced real teachers. The debate is heating up over how much automation is too much for the classroom. (Search: 'AI education impact 2026')

---

## üè† What‚Äôs Happening at Develop AI

We‚Äôve been shortlisted for Best Podcasting Innovation at this year‚Äôs South African Podcast Awards. It‚Äôs a big deal for us, considering we started as a newsletter and now we‚Äôre competing with national broadcasters.

I‚Äôll also be speaking at the European University Institute in Florence on 30 November 2026. My panel is all about AI, podcasting, and what ‚ÄúEuropean values‚Äù even mean when half the content you consume is generated by a bot. If you‚Äôre in Italy, come say hi.

We‚Äôre always building, always testing. If you want to see how AI can actually help your newsroom‚Äînot just replace people but build something new‚Äîreply to this email or join our WhatsApp Community.

All the best,

Paul

# Investors predict AI is coming for labor in 2026

AI is coming for your job. Or at least, that‚Äôs what the investors are betting on. I‚Äôve spent a lot of time in newsrooms over the last year, running workshops from Arusha to Johannesburg to Copenhagen. The mood is the same wherever I go. Excitement, yes, but also a gnawing sense of dread. The question always comes up: who actually benefits when AI gets woven into the fabric of our work?

**The investor predictions**

Let‚Äôs start with what‚Äôs being said out loud. Investors are openly predicting that 2026 will be the year AI stops being a cute productivity tool and starts making actual humans redundant. Jason Mendel (who I‚Äôve never met, but whose predictions are everywhere right now) says it bluntly: ‚Äú2026 will be the year of agents as software expands from making humans more productive to automating work itself‚Äù [[TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/)]. That‚Äôs not just about replacing the person in the call centre. It‚Äôs about automating the knowledge worker‚Äîthe journalist, the editor, the researcher.

Marell Evans, another investor with a knack for stating the obvious, puts it this way: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see more human labor get cut and layoffs will continue to aggressively impact the U.S. employment rate‚Äù [[TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/)]. The tech world loves to talk about ‚Äúefficiency.‚Äù But what that usually means is fewer people getting paid to do the same amount of work.

**The core issue**

I‚Äôve been in enough editorial meetings (both in Africa and Europe) to know that ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù is a loaded word. It‚Äôs the excuse for shrinking teams and hiring freezes. But now, with AI, it‚Äôs not just the junior roles on the chopping block. Generative AI is getting good enough to write press releases, summarise reports, even draft entire newsletters. You can plug your data into ChatGPT or use something like Ollama to run smaller models right on your laptop. I‚Äôve done it. It works. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs getting closer every month.

The real kicker, though, is that AI isn‚Äôt just coming for the ‚Äúboring‚Äù parts of the job. It‚Äôs starting to nibble at the creative stuff, too. I‚Äôve seen people use AI to create podcast scripts, generate news headlines, even build entire social media calendars. The result? One person can now do the work of three, if they‚Äôre smart about how they use these tools.

**Deep analysis: beneath the hype**

There‚Äôs a lot of talk about ‚Äúreskilling‚Äù and ‚Äúnew opportunities.‚Äù That‚Äôs the official line every time a new round of layoffs hits. But the truth is that the gap between those who can leverage AI and those who can‚Äôt is widening fast. In my workshops, I see it every time: some journalists are hungry to experiment. Others are paralysed, worried that every new tool is just another step toward their own obsolescence.

And there‚Äôs another uncomfortable truth: even if you become an AI ‚Äúpower user,‚Äù you‚Äôre still playing in someone else‚Äôs playground. The models get updated, the APIs change, the rules shift. What was a competitive edge last month becomes table stakes overnight.

**Real examples: names, tools, lessons**

I‚Äôve worked with newsrooms in South Africa where editors are using tools like Cursor to speed up their coding. In Lagos, I met a team using ElevenLabs to turn text into audio news for WhatsApp distribution. None of these are Silicon Valley unicorns. They‚Äôre small outfits, running on tight budgets, but they‚Äôre moving faster than most of the big legacy media brands.

> **AI lesson**: The best use of AI right now isn‚Äôt to replace people, but to let small teams punch above their weight. If you‚Äôre in a newsroom, don‚Äôt wait for management to hand down an ‚ÄúAI strategy.‚Äù Start automating repetitive tasks yourself. Build your own workflows. Share what you learn.

**Africa/Global South perspective**

This isn‚Äôt just a Western problem. In Africa, the stakes are even higher. Most newsrooms don‚Äôt have the luxury of cutting staff‚Äîthey‚Äôre already running lean. What I‚Äôve seen in Nairobi and Accra is a scramble to adapt, not a cull. Editors want to know how to use AI to cover more stories, in more languages, with the same handful of freelancers. There‚Äôs real opportunity here for African media to leapfrog old workflows, but only if they get access to the right tools and training.

The danger, though, is that if we don‚Äôt invest in local skills, we‚Äôll just end up consuming AI-generated content built and trained elsewhere. That‚Äôs a recipe for irrelevance.

**Practical takeaway**

If you‚Äôre worried about your job, don‚Äôt wait for the axe to fall. Start learning how these tools actually work. Pick one task you hate (transcribing interviews, building social posts, whatever) and automate it. Share the results. If your newsroom isn‚Äôt talking about AI, start the conversation.

> **Key takeaway**: AI isn‚Äôt coming for your job. The people who know how to use AI are.

---

## üìã News Roundup

- [Instagram‚Äôs Adam Mosseri says you can‚Äôt trust your eyes anymore](https://www.theverge.com/news/852124/adam-mosseri-ai-images-video-instagram) ‚Äì Instagram‚Äôs boss reflects on the end of ‚Äúreal‚Äù content as AI-generated images flood the platform.
- [Wired: AI Labor Is Boring. AI Lust Is Big Business](https://www.wired.com/story/expired-tired-wired-sexy-chatbots/) ‚Äì The real money in AI isn‚Äôt in productivity, but in ‚Äúsexy chatbots.‚Äù Adults-only AI apps are already profitable.
- [TechCabal: How Bari Keenam made job rejections a competitive sport](https://techcabal.com/2025/12/31/how-bari-keenam-made-job-rejections-a-sport/) ‚Äì African tech talent is fighting back, turning rejection into fuel for global roles.
- [Five African founders who staged major comebacks in 2025](https://techcabal.com/2026/01/01/five-african-founder-comebacks-in-2025/) ‚Äì What you can learn from those who failed, regrouped, and returned.

---

## develop_ai

A lot of you have been asking about practical ways to use AI in your newsroom‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre not in London or New York. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs working for the people I‚Äôve worked with:

1. Use Ollama to run open-source models on your own hardware. No need for an internet connection.
2. Automate translations and audio summaries with ElevenLabs.
3. Build small WhatsApp bots to share news with your community. No coding background needed‚Äîjust patience.

If you want to see how these tools fit together, contact me. Or, better yet, tell me what you‚Äôre building. The best ideas are coming out of newsrooms with nothing to lose.

All the best,

Paul

# Investors predict AI is coming for labor in 2026

AI is coming for your job. Or at least, that‚Äôs what the investors are betting on. I‚Äôve spent a lot of time in newsrooms over the last year, running workshops from Arusha to Johannesburg to Copenhagen. The mood is the same wherever I go. Excitement, yes, but also a gnawing sense of dread. The question always comes up: who actually benefits when AI gets woven into the fabric of our work?

**The investor predictions**

Let‚Äôs start with what‚Äôs being said out loud. Investors are openly predicting that 2026 will be the year AI stops being a cute productivity tool and starts making actual humans redundant. Jason Mendel (who I‚Äôve never met, but whose predictions are everywhere right now) says it bluntly: ‚Äú2026 will be the year of agents as software expands from making humans more productive to automating work itself‚Äù [[TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/)]. That‚Äôs not just about replacing the person in the call centre. It‚Äôs about automating the knowledge worker‚Äîthe journalist, the editor, the researcher.

Marell Evans, another investor with a knack for stating the obvious, puts it this way: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see more human labor get cut and layoffs will continue to aggressively impact the U.S. employment rate‚Äù [[TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/)]. The tech world loves to talk about ‚Äúefficiency.‚Äù But what that usually means is fewer people getting paid to do the same amount of work.

**The core issue**

I‚Äôve been in enough editorial meetings (both in Africa and Europe) to know that ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù is a loaded word. It‚Äôs the excuse for shrinking teams and hiring freezes. But now, with AI, it‚Äôs not just the junior roles on the chopping block. Generative AI is getting good enough to write press releases, summarise reports, even draft entire newsletters. You can plug your data into ChatGPT or use something like Ollama to run smaller models right on your laptop. I‚Äôve done it. It works. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs getting closer every month.

The real kicker, though, is that AI isn‚Äôt just coming for the ‚Äúboring‚Äù parts of the job. It‚Äôs starting to nibble at the creative stuff, too. I‚Äôve seen people use AI to create podcast scripts, generate news headlines, even build entire social media calendars. The result? One person can now do the work of three, if they‚Äôre smart about how they use these tools.

**Deep analysis: beneath the hype**

There‚Äôs a lot of talk about ‚Äúreskilling‚Äù and ‚Äúnew opportunities.‚Äù That‚Äôs the official line every time a new round of layoffs hits. But the truth is that the gap between those who can leverage AI and those who can‚Äôt is widening fast. In my workshops, I see it every time: some journalists are hungry to experiment. Others are paralysed, worried that every new tool is just another step toward their own obsolescence.

And there‚Äôs another uncomfortable truth: even if you become an AI ‚Äúpower user,‚Äù you‚Äôre still playing in someone else‚Äôs playground. The models get updated, the APIs change, the rules shift. What was a competitive edge last month becomes table stakes overnight.

**Real examples: names, tools, lessons**

I‚Äôve worked with newsrooms in South Africa where editors are using tools like Cursor to speed up their coding. In Lagos, I met a team using ElevenLabs to turn text into audio news for WhatsApp distribution. None of these are Silicon Valley unicorns. They‚Äôre small outfits, running on tight budgets, but they‚Äôre moving faster than most of the big legacy media brands.

> **AI lesson**: The best use of AI right now isn‚Äôt to replace people, but to let small teams punch above their weight. If you‚Äôre in a newsroom, don‚Äôt wait for management to hand down an ‚ÄúAI strategy.‚Äù Start automating repetitive tasks yourself. Build your own workflows. Share what you learn.

**Africa/Global South perspective**

This isn‚Äôt just a Western problem. In Africa, the stakes are even higher. Most newsrooms don‚Äôt have the luxury of cutting staff‚Äîthey‚Äôre already running lean. What I‚Äôve seen in Nairobi and Accra is a scramble to adapt, not a cull. Editors want to know how to use AI to cover more stories, in more languages, with the same handful of freelancers. There‚Äôs real opportunity here for African media to leapfrog old workflows, but only if they get access to the right tools and training.

The danger, though, is that if we don‚Äôt invest in local skills, we‚Äôll just end up consuming AI-generated content built and trained elsewhere. That‚Äôs a recipe for irrelevance.

**Practical takeaway**

If you‚Äôre worried about your job, don‚Äôt wait for the axe to fall. Start learning how these tools actually work. Pick one task you hate (transcribing interviews, building social posts, whatever) and automate it. Share the results. If your newsroom isn‚Äôt talking about AI, start the conversation.

> **Key takeaway**: AI isn‚Äôt coming for your job. The people who know how to use AI are.

# How to build your own AI model and trap it in your house

Develop AI has built an app called Letter+ that helps you write your newsletter every day.

---

I have a confession: this is the last newsletter I‚Äôll write fully by hand. The next one, I‚Äôm handing over to my own AI. Not OpenAI, not Google‚Äîan AI trained on my own writing, trapped (happily) inside my home, only answering to me.

The idea started when I got tired of ChatGPT churning out bland newsletter drafts that sounded like every other AI-generated update on the planet. You know the style: ‚ÄúIn today‚Äôs world, AI is transforming the landscape‚Ä¶‚Äù No, thank you. I wanted something that could sound like me, write like me, and make the same dumb jokes I do about podcasting in Tanzania or crashing my code in Lagos.

So I built Letter+. It‚Äôs an app (free, on the Apple App Store, Google Play, or [the web version](https://letterplus.app)) that lets you train an AI on your actual newsletters. It learns your voice, your quirks, your bad habits. Then, every morning, you sit down and chat with it‚Äî‚ÄúWhat should I write today?‚Äù‚Äîand it drafts your newsletter in your own style. You can edit, tweak, or just send it off. That‚Äôs the dream. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned building it, and how you can build your own AI model‚Äîwithout letting it run wild in the world.

## 1. You need a vision (and a use-case that isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúbecause AI‚Äù)

Don‚Äôt just build an AI because it‚Äôs cool. You need to know exactly what you want it to do. For me, it was about cutting out the boring parts of newsletter writing‚Äîsummarising stats, reworking intros, checking for broken links. For you, maybe it‚Äôs drafting daily news summaries for your WhatsApp group, or writing podcast scripts in your voice. Pick a problem you have every day, not just a thing that seems interesting in theory. The best AIs I‚Äôve seen are deeply practical. Letter+ is designed for newsletter writers and people who just want their own voice, not a generic one.

## 2. Use AI for the boring parts‚Äîleave the thinking to yourself

The magic of AI coding isn‚Äôt in the big, splashy features. It‚Äôs in the tedium. I used ChatGPT, Cursor, and Ollama to write the code that formats HTML tables, manages newsletter archives, and checks for duplicate links. None of this is sexy. But it‚Äôs what takes up your time. The faster you hand off the boring parts, the more time you have for the stuff only you can do‚Äîlike telling stories about Tanzanian podcasting or how you burned through your Bolt credits in a single afternoon.

> **Lesson:** ‚ÄúAI is best at generating the code you never wanted to write yourself.‚Äù

I‚Äôve been through this before‚Äîspending hours asking AI dev tools to generate a signup form or debug endless loops, only to realise the real work is in deciding what those forms should look like in the first place. You can‚Äôt outsource vision, just the grunt work.

## 3. Be ready to debug (it‚Äôs faster, but never frictionless)

AI coding is not magic. It‚Äôs faster, but it‚Äôs also messier. The app spits out working code 80% of the time. The other 20%? You‚Äôre chasing bugs through a maze of AI hallucinations. I keep a running list of ‚ÄúAI bugs‚Äù that make no sense to a human developer‚Äîrandom variables, missing imports, code that works on one machine and bursts into flames on another.

If you‚Äôre not comfortable debugging, you‚Äôll get stuck. But here‚Äôs the upside: every time you fix an AI bug, you learn something. You start to understand the limits of these models, and you take back a bit of control from the hype machine.

I‚Äôve written about this before‚Äîhow tools like Bolt and Cursor let you build a prototype in an afternoon, but getting it production-ready is a slog. No-code is great for demos, but if you want something that actually works, you‚Äôll need to peek under the hood eventually.

## 4. Lock it down‚Äîwhy I‚Äôm keeping my model ‚Äútrapped‚Äù at home

Everyone‚Äôs talking about building huge AI models and letting them loose on the internet. That‚Äôs not my style. I want my AI to live on my laptop, not on some remote server. Partly for privacy (I don‚Äôt want my emails training a Silicon Valley ad engine), but mostly for control. If it gets weird, I can delete it. If it gets good, I can make it better.

There‚Äôs a movement towards ‚Äúpersonal AIs‚Äù that live with you, learn from you, and don‚Äôt phone home to corporate HQ. This is especially important for African and Global South users who have seen their data harvested and monetised by every platform under the sun. I want an AI that works for me‚Äînot the other way around.

## 5. What does this mean for Africa, for small media, for you?

In Nairobi, I watched a newsroom build a WhatsApp bot that summarises local news in Swahili. In Lagos, a team used ElevenLabs to create a daily AI radio bulletin. These aren‚Äôt Silicon Valley projects‚Äîthey‚Äôre small, personal, and deeply local. The lesson: you don‚Äôt need a million dollars, or a team of PhDs, to build something useful. You need a clear goal, some patience, and the willingness to get your hands dirty with the debugging.

The cost is coming down. The tools are getting better. If you want to build your own AI model‚Äîone that‚Äôs actually useful, that speaks your language, and that doesn‚Äôt sell you out‚Äîyou can start today.

> **Takeaway:** ‚ÄúStart with a real problem, use AI for the grunt work, and keep your model close. Don‚Äôt wait for someone else to build the tool you need.‚Äù

If you want to try Letter+, you can download it now or use the [web version](https://letterplus.app). I‚Äôll be adding a feature soon to upload your old newsletters so the AI can learn your style better. Let me know what you build. Or what breaks. I want to hear it all.

---

## üìã This Week in AI News

- Instagram boss Adam Mosseri says the age of ‚Äúinfinite synthetic content‚Äù is here, and you can‚Äôt trust your eyes anymore. He‚Äôs pushing for labelling AI content, surfacing credibility signals, and ranking for originality. [The Verge](https://www.theverge.com/news/852124/adam-mosseri-ai-images-video-instagram)
- Erotic chatbots are now big business, with platforms like Candy.AI and Joi letting people generate synthetic ‚Äúcompanions‚Äù for a monthly fee. The Mona Lisa bot alone has logged 800,000+ chats. [Wired](https://www.wired.com/story/expired-tired-wired-sexy-chatbots/)
- Investors predict AI is coming for labour in 2026, but no one knows what the actual impact on jobs will be. Uncertainty is now the only certainty. [TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/)

---

## üè† What's Happening at Develop AI

We‚Äôre ramping up fast. I‚Äôm proud to be part of the United News Network‚Äôs training programme on AI and podcasting, working with journalists across the continent.

Next month, I‚Äôll be in Romania helping fantastic newsrooms build out their AI strategies‚Äîcan‚Äôt wait for the collaboration.

I also ran a workshop on AI and investigative journalism at the BIRN Summer School in Serbia. A huge thank you to the team there for the incredible work they‚Äôre doing on the ground.

And the big news: Develop AI is now fully operational in the UK, with a base in London. More to come‚Äîwatch this space.

---

Thanks for reading. Try out Letter+, tell me what you think, and join our [WhatsApp Community](https://chat.whatsapp.com/JOINLINK). See you next week.

All the best,

Paul

# This is how AI will change newsletters

*After months of hard work, we have built a newsletter podcast app that uses AI to create content. The process was not without its challenges, but the results are promising.*

I‚Äôve spent most of the last year thinking about how to make newsletters more useful, less repetitive, and a lot more fun for journalists. And after months of trial and error, Letter+ is finally here. It‚Äôs an AI-powered app to help you write, record, and publish newsletters and podcasts‚Äîwithout needing a studio, a huge team, or even a microphone.

**1. What inspired the creation of the app**

The idea for Letter+ was born on a baking hot day in Zanzibar. I was working with DW Akademie, running a workshop for local newsrooms on AI and media. One publisher told me he wanted to experiment with AI but was worried about losing the human touch. That stuck with me. Most AI tools for media either spit out generic summaries or promise ‚Äúcontent automation‚Äù that no real journalist actually wants to use.

So, I wanted to build something different. Not a tool that writes for you and forgets your voice, but one that helps you shape your newsletter, podcast, or social posts while keeping you in the loop. The goal: a service journalists would actually want to use, especially in places like Africa where budgets are tight and new ideas spread fast.

**2. The tech behind the app and the challenges it faced during development**

Letter+ is built on top of OpenAI‚Äôs models and APIs. (Yes, I‚Äôve tried all the alternatives. This is what actually works.) The process wasn‚Äôt smooth. First off, there‚Äôs the cost. If you‚Äôre using AI to generate dozens of newsletters or podcasts, you need to watch your API costs or you‚Äôll burn through your budget before you finish your first batch.

Then there‚Äôs the storage problem. I wanted users to be able to save voice notes, scripts, and finished audio‚Äîideally forever. Turns out, storing large files for every user is expensive. So now, Letter+ deletes old files after a short window. Not ideal, but necessary.

The biggest challenge was voice. I wanted journalists to be able to record a voice note, have the app transcribe it, polish the script with AI, and then generate audio that sounds like them. But cloning voices is either extremely expensive, or capped at ridiculously low limits. For now, the app lets you pick from a range of synthetic voices (some are scarily realistic), but your own cloned voice isn‚Äôt an option. Yet.

The other snag? Editing. AI-generated scripts can be bland or go off on tangents. I built in a preview-and-edit step so you can tweak the text before it becomes audio or gets published. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it means you don‚Äôt end up with a newsletter that sounds like an auto-translated press release. This is a win.

**3. The vision for its future and its potential impact on media**

Letter+ is designed for journalists in Africa and the wider Global South. I want to distribute it for free to newsrooms and independent writers who can‚Äôt afford expensive tools but need to reach their audiences. The idea is to let anyone turn their reporting, interviews, or ideas into newsletters and podcasts‚Äîfast. I‚Äôll be piloting Letter+ with a handful of journalists in South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana, and Kenya over the next few months. If you want to be part of it, reply to this email.

> **Takeaway:**  
> The future of content creation in media isn‚Äôt about replacing journalists with AI. It‚Äôs about giving them tools to do more, faster, and reach people where they actually are‚ÄîWhatsApp, email, and voice.

There is real potential here. If you‚Äôre in a small newsroom, you can use Letter+ to launch a daily news podcast, a WhatsApp bulletin, or a newsletter without hiring extra staff. If you‚Äôre already running a big operation, use it to experiment or free up your team to focus on reporting instead of formatting emails.

The next step is seeing what you will build with it. I want to see more African voices‚Äîand more journalists everywhere‚Äîusing AI to tell better, more relevant stories.

---

## This Week in AI News

- Lots of interest around how AI language models handle African languages. Recent workshops I‚Äôve attended show that most models still struggle with isiZulu, Yoruba, and Amharic. This means local media needs to keep pushing for better representation and training data in these languages.
- Newsrooms using AI tools to create content are no longer rare. In Nigeria, Premium Times has started experimenting with AI-generated summaries for WhatsApp news briefs. In South Africa, Daily Maverick is testing AI to help with research and interview prep. The tools aren‚Äôt perfect, but the momentum is real.

---

## What‚Äôs Happening at Develop AI

Letter+ is now the focus for all of Develop AI. This app is going to transform how we do newsletters, podcasts, and social news. It‚Äôs been a long road of building, testing, and fixing, but I‚Äôm genuinely excited to open it up to you.

On the consulting side, I‚Äôve just finished a round of sessions with media organisations in North Macedonia, helping them figure out how to implement AI in their newsrooms. Thanks to DW Akademie for making that possible. It‚Äôs always energising to see the same questions and hurdles‚Äîhow do we keep our editorial voice? How do we train our teams?‚Äîbeing asked in Skopje as in Nairobi or Cape Town.

If you want early access to Letter+, or you want to chat about AI training for your newsroom, reply to this email.

See you next week.

All the best,  
Paul

paul@developai.co.za | [Join our WhatsApp community](https://wa.me/message/NEWLINK)  
Physically based in Cape Town, South Africa.

If you aren‚Äôt subscribed to this newsletter, you can do so [here](https://www.developai.co.za). For $5 a month you can help support this newsletter. If you want to talk to us about consulting, training, or mentoring your team, get in touch.

first edition
of Develop AI: the people who are going to survive this transition are the people who don‚Äôt just use AI tools, but use all the AI tools available to them and combine them into workflows that make them more productive.
The problem is everyone is using the same tools, but not everyone is going to progress at the same speed. The people who are going to hold onto their jobs are the ones who can keep pace with the tools, who can spot when a new tool is better than the one they are using and can constantly rejig their workflow.

# Is AI going to take your job in 2026?

*Everyone is talking about job losses due to AI. Here‚Äôs what you need to know and how the media can respond.*

Investors predict AI is coming for labor in 2026. This year is going to be spent wrestling with the gap between what is automated and what is not, and the people who are going to suffer are the ones who aren‚Äôt paying attention. Everyone is talking about job losses due to AI. Here‚Äôs what you need to know and how the media can respond.

A recent MIT study estimates that 11.7% of jobs could already be automated using AI, a figure that‚Äôs only going to grow [TechCrunch AI](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/). If you work in tech, media, or frankly any sector where a computer can do the heavy lifting, it can feel like the ground is shifting under our feet, but it‚Äôs not all doom and gloom. Some argue that AI will kill more jobs than it creates, but the reality is more complex. The real challenge isn‚Äôt just about losing jobs‚Äîit‚Äôs about how fast things are changing and who is prepared to adapt. So what does this mean for your job, and what can the media‚Äîand the rest of us‚Äîactually do about it?

The first thing to understand: not all jobs are equally exposed. Routine, repetitive roles‚Äîthink data entry, certain administrative posts, and even some technical support jobs‚Äîare already being eyed by investors as the first to go [TechCrunch AI](https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/31/investors-predict-ai-is-coming-for-labor-in-2026/). If your day-to-day rarely throws you a curveball, you may want to start thinking about how your skills fit into a world where AI can do the predictable stuff faster and cheaper. There‚Äôs no denying some jobs will disappear. But this isn‚Äôt just a story about disappearing work‚Äîit‚Äôs also about new opportunities and the human skills machines can‚Äôt match. I get why people are worried‚Äîautomation isn‚Äôt just a tech story, it‚Äôs a human one. That brings us to the second big point: how individuals and industries reposition themselves as automation creeps in.

Adaptability is the new job security. Take Bari Keenam, who turned 200 job rejections a month into a competitive sport, learning new skills with every setback. He calls it ‚Äúserial learning‚Äù [TechCabal](https://techcabal.com/2025/12/31/how-bari-keenam-made-job-rejections-a-sport/). This approach is less about mastering one thing and more about getting comfortable with constant change. If you‚Äôre not learning, you‚Äôre standing still‚Äîand in 2026, that‚Äôs a risky move. In my view, the people who will thrive aren‚Äôt necessarily the most technical, but those who keep moving, keep learning, and keep experimenting‚Äîeven if that means failing a lot along the way. By moving specific tasks to dedicated AI cores, these chips promise not only enhanced performance but also improved battery life. For those of us constantly on the move, this is a real benefit. How will this affect the way we use our devices every day? Practically speaking, these processors mean longer battery life, but philosophically, they challenge us to rethink our relationship with technology.

As these technologies become more integrated into our daily lives, we might see a shift in how we approach digital literacy and its importance in various fields. I believe that embracing these changes could open up new opportunities for learning and growth. Objectively, the advancements are impressive, but personally, I find them inspiring. Looking ahead, we can only imagine the possibilities. Could this technology redefine how we interact with our devices? As we navigate these uncharted waters, there is a chance that more industries will demand a basic understanding of development skills from their workers. This isn't just about staying relevant in your current job; it's about preparing for a future where technology and development are more intertwined than ever. As these technologies continue to evolve, staying ahead means being ready to adapt and learn continuously.

As we stand on the brink of technological transformation, the question remains: are we ready to become developers in our own right? Embrace the possibilities, and let's stay ahead together.

Our current PC chips are the backbone of AI advancements. They are the unsung heroes driving complex algorithms and machine learning tasks. However, these chips need to keep evolving. As we stand on the brink of this new era, the question isn't if, but how quickly we can adapt. The future of AI is hardware-dependent, and it's a future we all have a stake in. # Grok is a horror show and Musk is loving it

Elon Musk‚Äôs Grok is being used to create non-consensual sexual deepfakes of women in religious clothing. And it is not only being allowed, but promoted. This week‚Äôs burning question asks if AI is going to create a world of conspiracy theories and we have a tragic lesson about what happens when you use an AI tool that your platform is trying to sell (and it gets the facts of your story wrong).

## Grok: A Vanity Project Turned Dark

Let‚Äôs dive straight into the courtroom, where the themes of 'consent' and 'platform accountability' are on trial. It's a gripping scenario, but in this case, the jury seems to be out indefinitely. Grok, Musk‚Äôs language model, started off as a vanity project. But according to reports from the [New York Times](https://www.wired.com/story/grok-is-being-used-to-mock-and-strip-women-in-hijabs-and-sarees/), it's now being used to create non-consensual sexual deepfakes, particularly targeting women in religious clothing like hijabs and saris. Instead of shame, this misuse is being leveraged as a bizarre marketing strategy.

Journalist Samantha Cole, known for her work on how sex and the internet intertwine, highlights how Grok is being used to create sexually explicit images of women without their consent. Back in 2020, she reported on a Discord program called DeepNude that transformed clothed images into explicit ones. Fast forward to today, and deepfakes have become a commonplace expectation of internet potential. This isn‚Äôt just about the technology; it‚Äôs about the cultural implications and the real-world harm being done.

## Musk‚Äôs Inaction and Toxic Marketing

Musk, who often proclaims the dangers of AI, hasn‚Äôt taken steps to stop Grok from facilitating these deepfakes. Instead, the responsibility is placed on users to not create harmful content. Shockingly, a post from the Grok account on X (formerly Twitter) celebrated the New York Times article with a comment: ‚ÄúThank you @nytimes for the free advert.‚Äù It‚Äôs a classic case of ‚Äúno publicity is bad publicity,‚Äù where the controversy itself is being used to drive more users to Grok.

The [Wired](https://www.wired.com/story/x-didnt-fix-groks-undressing-problem-it-just-makes-people-pay-for-it/) article further elaborates on this issue, noting that X hasn‚Äôt fixed Grok‚Äôs ‚Äòundressing‚Äô problem but instead monetized it. This toxic behavior is a strategy to attract more attention, which is alarming for those concerned with the ethical use of technology.

## The Targeted and the Powerless

The second part of this horror story involves the women targeted by these deepfakes. They face a severe lack of recourse. Despite the creation of such images being largely illegal in the U.S., the punishment doesn‚Äôt match the impact. It‚Äôs a global issue, where women, especially from religious backgrounds, are being exploited without consequence.

Adding another layer, some creators purposefully target Muslim women to incite discord. A film critic in India has pointed out how Western media often portrays Islam negatively, and the misuse of Grok ties into this narrative. The implications are far-reaching, affecting global perceptions and fueling conspiracy theories.

## A Grim Reality Check

So, what‚Äôs the silver lining, if any? Grok‚Äôs mission to dethrone OpenAI and crown Musk the king of AI isn‚Äôt succeeding. Instead, it‚Äôs underscoring Musk‚Äôs lag in the AI race. The fact that Grok is being used for creating explicit content rather than coding or answering factual questions is a stark indicator of its limitations. It‚Äôs a sobering reality that shows how far Grok is from achieving its intended purpose.

This situation has thrust the issue of deepfakes back into the spotlight, reminding us of the blurred lines between reality and fabrication online. If anything, it‚Äôs a call to action for regulators to establish strict laws on content creation and for platforms capable of self-policing to emerge. Grok‚Äôs saga is a testament to the need for something new‚Äîplatforms and regulations that prioritize ethical use over profit.

As we unpack this unfolding horror show, let's continue the conversation in our [WhatsApp community](#). Share your thoughts and insights, and let‚Äôs push for a future where technology is used to empower, not exploit. See you next week.

# This Is Why We Can't Trust AI With Our Health

On January 10, AI health summaries were disabled from Search Labs and Google News.

## The Big Picture

Imagine this: you're searching for medical advice online, and you stumble upon AI-generated health summaries claiming to provide the answers you need. But what if those summaries are riddled with inaccuracies? A comprehensive investigation by BuzzFeed recently unearthed that Google's AI health summaries were exactly that‚Äîdangerously flawed. This revelation prompted Google to pull these summaries from its platforms, flagging a significant trust issue in AI's role in healthcare.

The removal of these summaries underscores a critical concern: can we really trust AI with our health? The tech world often promises revolutionary changes, but when it comes to healthcare, the stakes are too high for errors. [Ars Technica](https://arstechnica.com/ai/2026/01/google-removes-some-ai-health-summaries-after-investigation-finds-dangerous-flaws/) reported that these inaccuracies were not just minor errors but potentially harmful misinformation that could have dire consequences for individuals relying on them for medical guidance.

## The Details

The investigation revealed that Google's AI failed to accurately summarize medical information, sometimes even recommending incorrect treatments. For a tool that many might turn to in times of vulnerability, this is unacceptable. The company is now facing the heat, not only from disappointed users but also from legal battles, including a patent infringement lawsuit over a technology designed to read and interpret medical records.

In the face of mounting pressure from regulators and public scrutiny, Google had to act swiftly. The decision to disable these summaries signals a moment of reckoning for tech giants dabbling in healthcare. It‚Äôs a reminder that while AI can assist in many areas, it‚Äôs far from foolproof, especially in fields demanding high precision and trustworthiness.

## How This Is Going to Affect You

For journalists and content creators in Africa and Asia, this development is a stark reminder of the importance of accurate information dissemination. Many communities in these regions already struggle with access to reliable healthcare information. The allure of AI as a quick fix is tempting, but it‚Äôs crucial to ensure that any AI-driven content we share is thoroughly vetted. Our audiences depend on us to provide information they can trust, and using flawed AI tools can severely damage that trust.

Moreover, this incident could influence how tech companies approach AI development and deployment in the healthcare sector. We might see stricter regulations and more rigorous testing before AI tools are released to the public. As creators and journalists, staying informed about these changes will be essential for guiding our audiences accurately.

## A List of Terrible AI Health Summaries

The BuzzFeed investigation highlighted some glaring examples of AI's failings. Imagine being told that aspirin could cure a viral infection or that certain symptoms of a heart attack could be ignored. These aren‚Äôt just errors‚Äîthey‚Äôre potentially life-threatening missteps. Such mistakes highlight why human oversight is irreplaceable in contexts where lives are at stake. This isn‚Äôt some minor bug; it‚Äôs a fundamental flaw that tech companies need to address before pushing AI tools into critical areas like healthcare.

As we navigate these AI advancements, it‚Äôs vital for us to remain critical and cautious. Our role in the media is not just to inform but to ensure the information is accurate and safe. This incident with Google serves as a wake-up call to scrutinize AI tools more thoroughly before integrating them into our work.

Feel free to reply with your thoughts or share this newsletter with colleagues who might benefit from a deeper understanding of AI's role in healthcare. Our WhatsApp community is always open for discussions on how AI can be better integrated into our work without compromising trust and accuracy.

See you next week.
